title: Lesson 8: The Fluid Mosaic Model
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding the fluid mosaic model of cell membranes including phospholipid bilayer structure, membrane proteins, cholesterol, and temperature effects on membrane fluidity.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the fluid mosaic model of the cell membrane (phospholipid bilayer, proteins, cholesterol, carbohydrates).
Students can explain the arrangement of phospholipids (hydrophilic heads outward, hydrophobic tails inward) based on the aqueous environment.
Students can predict how temperature affects membrane fluidity and explain the role of cholesterol in stabilising membranes.

engagementHook.title: The Dynamic Border
engagementHook.content: Show two videos: a cell membrane at 37°C (fluid, components moving) vs at 4°C (rigid, crystalline). 'Your cell membranes are not solid walls - they're fluid, dynamic sheets that change with temperature. How can a layer of fat molecules stay flexible in the heat but not fall apart? The answer lies in the fluid mosaic and a molecule called cholesterol.'

keyConcepts.definition: The membrane is a flexible (fluid) layer of phospholipids with proteins embedded (mosaic pattern). Proposed by Singer and Nicolson in 1972.

Two layers of phospholipids. Hydrophilic (water-loving) phosphate heads face aqueous environments inside and outside cell. Hydrophobic (water-fearing) fatty acid tails face each other in membrane interior.
Span the entire membrane (transmembrane). Functions: transport channels, receptors, enzymes.
Attached to membrane surface (not spanning). Functions: enzymes, structural support, cell signalling.

Fits between phospholipids in animal cell membranes. At high temperatures: restrains phospholipid movement (reduces fluidity). At low temperatures: prevents tight packing (maintains fluidity). Stabilises membrane fluidity across temperatures.
Carbohydrate chains attached to proteins or lipids on the extracellular surface. Functions: cell-cell recognition, immune response (self vs non-self), ABO blood typing.

misconceptions.correction: Emphasise 'fluid' - components move laterally (fluidity). Phospholipids can diffuse sideways.
Cholesterol MODERATES fluidity - reduces it at high temps, increases it at low temps. Acts as a buffer.

misconceptions.misconception: Proteins are just stuck on the surface
misconceptions.correction: Integral proteins span the membrane; only peripheral proteins are surface-bound.

contentSections.title: The Phospholipid Bilayer
contentSections.content: Two layers of phospholipids (spherical heads with two tails) arranged heads-out, tails-in. Hydrophilic heads contact water; hydrophobic tails shielded from water in membrane interior.
keyPoints: Hydrophobic fatty acid tails face each other
Creates hydrophobic core - barrier to polar molecules
contentSections.example: Soap bubbles form similar bilayer structures - hydrophilic outside, hydrophobic inside.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why do phospholipids form bilayers rather than single layers in water? (Tails need to be shielded from water on both sides)

contentSections.title: ABO Blood Groups
contentSections.content: Carbohydrate chains on red blood cell surface determine blood type. Type A has specific sugar (N-acetylgalactosamine), Type B has different sugar (galactose), Type AB has both, Type O has neither. Immune system recognises these as 'self.' Transfusion mismatch causes immune reaction.
contentSections.example: Type A person has anti-B antibodies. If given Type B blood, antibodies attack the B antigens on donor cells.

multipleChoice.question: In the fluid mosaic model of the cell membrane, the 'mosaic' refers to:
options: The phospholipids arranged in a pattern
The proteins embedded in the phospholipid bilayer
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: The proteins embedded in the phospholipid bilayer
multipleChoice.rationale: Mosaic refers to the scattered pattern of proteins embedded throughout the phospholipid bilayer.

multipleChoice.question: What is the function of cholesterol in the plasma membrane?
options: To transport glucose across the membrane
To attach cells to each other
multipleChoice.rationale: Cholesterol reduces fluidity at high temperatures and prevents tight packing at low temperatures, stabilising the membrane across temperature ranges.

multipleChoice.question: The hydrophobic tails of phospholipids face:
options: The aqueous environment outside the cell
The aqueous cytoplasm inside the cell
Each other in the interior of the membrane
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Each other in the interior of the membrane
multipleChoice.rationale: Hydrophobic tails are excluded from water and face each other in the membrane interior, creating a hydrophobic core.

shortAnswer.question: Describe the arrangement of phospholipids in the cell membrane and explain how this arrangement creates a barrier to polar molecules but allows non-polar molecules to cross. [3 marks]
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Phospholipids arranged in a bilayer (two layers)
1 mark: Hydrophilic heads face outward (aqueous environments), hydrophobic tails face inward
1 mark: Hydrophobic core repels polar/hydrophilic molecules but allows non-polar/lipid-soluble molecules to pass through
shortAnswer.commonError: Not explaining WHY the hydrophobic core acts as a barrier (water exclusion).

shortAnswer.question: Explain how cholesterol helps maintain membrane fluidity across different temperatures. [2 marks]
markingCriteria: 1 mark: At high temperatures: cholesterol restricts phospholipid movement, reducing fluidity
1 mark: At low temperatures: cholesterol prevents tight packing of phospholipids, maintaining fluidity / preventing solidification
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying cholesterol always increases fluidity (it moderates/buffers in both directions).

definitions: Fluid mosaic model: Phospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins; membrane is flexible (fluid) with scattered protein pattern (mosaic).
Phospholipids: Hydrophilic heads face water; hydrophobic tails face each other in membrane interior.
Integral proteins span the membrane; peripheral proteins are surface-bound.
Cholesterol stabilises membrane fluidity: reduces fluidity at high temps, prevents solidification at low temps.
Glycoproteins/glycolipids on outer surface function in cell recognition (e.g., ABO blood groups).
keyPoints: Hydrophobic core prevents polar molecules crossing
Cholesterol acts as a fluidity buffer across temperatures
diagrams: Fluid mosaic model with all components labelled
Phospholipid structure showing head and tails

shortAnswer: Phospholipids are arranged in a bilayer with their hydrophilic (water-loving) phosphate heads facing outward toward the aqueous environments inside and outside the cell, and their hydrophobic (water-fearing) fatty acid tails facing inward toward each other. This creates a hydrophobic core in the centre of the membrane. This arrangement creates a barrier to polar molecules because the hydrophobic core repels water and polar substances. However, non-polar molecules (lipid-soluble substances) can dissolve in the hydrophobic interior and pass through the membrane easily.

Cholesterol helps maintain membrane fluidity across different temperatures by acting as a buffer. At high temperatures, cholesterol restrains the movement of phospholipids, reducing fluidity and preventing the membrane from becoming too fluid. At low temperatures, cholesterol prevents phospholipids from packing too tightly together, maintaining fluidity and preventing the membrane from solidifying. This ensures the membrane remains functional across a range of temperatures.
